interventions.interventions: This is a patient Registry collecting information on patients with a diagnosis of sickle cell disease, alpha-thalassemia, beta-thalassemia and other haemoglobinopathies. Information will be collected by review of medical records for a period of five years.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Survival assessed by review of hospital medical records

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Variation in treatment assessed by hospital records

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients with a diagnosis of sickle cell disease, alpha-thalassemia, beta-thalassemia and other haemoglobinopathies.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: patients who have chosen to opt-off the registry.

trial_design.statisticalmethods:
A detailed pre-determined statistical plan will be developed prior to planned analyses of registry data.
Analysis plans will be reviewed by the Steering Committee and by a suitably qualified statistician prior to data from the Haemoglobinopathy Registry being analysed.

recruitment.hospital: Monash Medical Centre - Clayton campus - Clayton
The Children's Hospital at Westmead - Westmead
Lady Cilento Children's Hospital - South Brisbane
Womens and Childrens Hospital - North Adelaide

fundingsource.fundingaddress: level 7 607 St Kilda Road Melbourne Victoria 3004

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The primary purpose of this study is to provide long-term patient follow-up and review of clinical and correlative data outside of clinical trials.
Who is it for? The registry will collect information on patients with a diagnosis of sickle cell disease, alpha-thalassemia, beta-thalassemia and other haemoglobinopathies.
Study Details Treating clinicians at sites will identify patients and enrol them to the study. The following categories of data items will be collected to the Haemoglobinopathy database using a web portal: Demographic details Clinical presentation Laboratory results Therapy Complications (of therapy or condition) Outcomes
It is hoped that the findings from this study will identify patterns of treatment and variation in outcomes, for survival and quality of life. Findings will be valuable in informing optimal treatment strategies.
